events.title: Turning Point Achieved: R.A.F. Defeats Day Raids by September 30, 1940
events.description: R.A.F., the enemy effort was so decisively beaten that though attacks continued by day until 30th September, 1940, it was undoubtedly then that the turning-point of the battle against the day raider had been reached.

events.title: Anti-Aircraft Command Claims Victory: 370 Enemy Aircraft Neutralized in Summer of 1940
events.description: From roth July, 1940, the day which most authorities have accepted as the opening day of the battle, until 30th September, 1940, the guns of Anti-Aircraft Command destroyed by day 296 enemy aircraft and damaged or probably destroyed a further 74.

events.title: Sky Supremacy: Air Operations from D-Day to September 30, 1944
events.description: Brief Summary of Air Effort for the period D-Day to 30th September, 1944

events.title: Allied Forces Surge: 117 Days of Liberation and Unmatched Air Operation Efforts
events.description: 403. At 30th September, the Allied armies stood on and in some places, over the borders of the Reich proper. In 117 days since the assault began, France, Belgium, Luxembourg and a large part of Holland had been liberated. These 117 days.had also been unprecedented in the scale of air effort employed. The aircraft of A.E.A.F. alone had flown 316,248 sorties, an average of 2,703 per day. The effort of the strategical air forces based in the United Kingdom raised this total to 552,197 sorties, an average of 4,719 per day.

events.title: Grim Toll of War: Personnel Casualties Reveal Heavy Losses from April to September 1944
events.description: 408. Personnel Casualties. The following statistics of personnel casualties cover the period from rst April to 30th September, 1944. These figures reveal a grievous loss of highly trained men. Reference, however, to the statistics in paragraph 183, dealing with the

events.title: Unexpectedly Low Enemy Air Efforts Mark D-Day to September End
events.description: 340. The enemy scale of effort throughout the whole period D-Day to 30th September was considerably lower than was expected. As I have already stated, I had expected at the outset a week of fairly heavy air attacks, after which I felt confident that the enemy air effort would dwindle and require much less attention from our own air forces. In fact no serious air battle took place during this period.

events.title: Summer Surge: Visitor Numbers Soar to Over 16,000 in Just Four Months
events.description: 6th-30th June ... 2,400 Ist-31st July 3,364 Ist-31st August ... te see 4,091 1st-30th September... os 6,238 16,093

events.title: Era of Jet-Powered Warfare Begins: G.A.F. Unveils Groundbreaking Aircraft
events.description: 359. Enemy use of Jet-propelled Aircraft. The most important feature of G.A.F. activity during the second half of September was the appearance of jet-propelled aircraft, at first in ones and twos, later in fours and fives. In view of the fact that within the period covered by this Despatch (namely until 30th September) we have had insufficient experience of them to form reliable estimates of their activities or capabilities, I do not propose to comment on them at length. That they are a momentous landmark in the history of the air will not be denied, but final judgment on their value must be reserved for the moment.

events.title: Heavy Enemy Casualties Recorded on Western Front: June to September 1944
events.description: Enemy Losses on the Western Front 6th June-30th September, 1944

events.title: Optimistic Findings: Low Sortie Losses from D-Day to September 30th
events.description: preparatory period and paragraph 403, cover- will show that the overall losses per sorties ing the period from D-Day to 30th September, flown are reasonably low.

events.title: Allied Air Forces Face Heavy Losses in Western Europe: Casualty Report for April-September 1944
events.description: Personnel Casualties of Allied Air Forces Operating in Western Europe Period 1st April-30th September, 1944

events.title: Final Report: A Commanderâ€™s Reflections on the Allied Air Force Operations, Nov '43 - Sept '44
events.description: On relinquishing my command of the Allied Expeditionary Air Force I have the honour to submit the following Despatch, covering its operations under my command during the period from 15th November, 1943 tof 30th September, 1944.

events.title: R.A.F. Coastal Command Strikes Hard: Twelve U-Boats Sunk as Allies Gain Ground
events.description: 390. With the Allied advance in August, the enemy began to move his U-boats away from the ports of North-Western France to the southern portion of the Bay of Biscay This movement gave the aircraft of R.A.F, Coastal Command a splendid chance to strike. 24 sightings were made in the Bay during August, and 14 attacks resulted; six U-boats were probably sunk, three of these shared with Naval forces, and two more damaged. From D-Day to 30th September, R.A.F. Coastal Command sunk or probably sunk 12 U-boats in the Channel or the Bay of Biscay, shared the destruction of five more with surface forces and damaged a further 12.

events.title: Air Assault Analysis: A.E.A.F. Dominates D-Day to September with Ground-Level Strikes
events.description: 365. The following statistics show the weight of bombing attacks on airfields in the period D-Day to 30th September. The chief contribution of the aircraft of A.E.A.F, was, however, in low level strafing and destruction of aircraft on the ground.

events.title: Historic Air Offensive: Total Sorties Target Airfields from June to September 1944
events.description: Total Sorties against Airfields during the period 6th June to 30th September, 1944

events.title: Fighter Jets Intercept 1,915 Flying Bombs in 24,572 Sorties Amidst Ongoing Threat
events.description: 369. From the commencement of flying bomb activity until 30th September, fighter aircraft flew 24,572 sorties on interception patrols. This commitment was almost exclusively met by the aircraft of A.D.G.B. These patrols accounted for 1,915 flying bombs out of a total of 7,503 launched. The following figures give the results of all types of defence against these weapons :

events.title: Historic Timeframe: June 12/13 to September 30, 1944, Captured in Memoir
events.description: Period 12/13th June to 2100 hours 30th September, 1944

events.title: Devastation from Above: A Summer of Flying Bomb Attacks (June 12 - September 30, 1944)
events.description: Flying Bombs Destroyed period 12/13th June to 30th September, 1944

events.title: Heroes of the Skies: Air/Sea Rescue Services Save Hundreds from June to September 1944
events.description: 440. Statistics of Personnel Rescued. The following figures show the totals of personnel rescued by the Air/Sea Rescue Services of A.D.G.B, and R.A.F. Coastal Command for the period 6th June to 30th September, 1944:

events.title: Air Evacuations Skyrocket: Over 107,000 Medical Cases Airlifted Since D-Day
events.description: returning to the United Kingdom after delivering supplies. This policy was naturally not always popular with the medical authorities, but no relaxation of it was found to be necessarysave in conditions of extreme urgency. This policy was fully supported by you. In all, during the period from D-Day to 30th September, 107,115 medical cases were evacuated by air from forward positions.

events.title: Revisiting D-Day to September 30, 1944: A Tactical Overview of Key Operations
events.description: 234. .As in the previous sections of the narrative part of this Despatch, I propose to deal with the operations in the period D-Day to 30th September, 1944, under types of operations, rather than on a time basis. For this purpose the following headings have been adopted:

events.title: World War II: A.E.A.F. Conducts Nearly 19,000 Reconnaissance Sorties Post D-Day
events.description: 263. In the period D-Day to 30th September, 1944, the reconnaissance umts of A.E.A.F. flew 4,808 sorties on photographic and 14,140 sorties on visual reconnaissances, a total of 18,948 sorties.

events.title: Heavy Bombers Strike: Major Assaults Target Enemy Garrisons from D-Day to September
events.description: 266. Much of the work of the squadrons engaged on armed reconnaissance I have described in the preceding paragraphs dealing with attacks on communications. In addition to the pre-arranged support by medium and fighter bombers (dealt with later in paragraph 284 et seq.), there were six large scale attacks by heavy bombers during the period D-Day to 30th September, apart from certain other attacks on the enemy garrisons left in the Channel ports.

events.title: Historic Naval Passage: NELSON's Journey to Gibraltar on September 29th/30th
events.description: Passage of NELSON to Gibraltar, 29th/30th September (D.5/6). .

events.title: Prince of Wales Leads Fleet Ahead of Schedule to Gibraltar by September 30
events.description: 159. PRINCE OF WALES, KENYA, SHEFFIELD, LAFOREY, LIGHTNING, ORIBI, FORESIGHT, FORESTER and FURY parted company from the remainder of the force at 1930 and proceeded ahead in order to arrive at Gibraltar p.m. 30th September.

events.title: Home Fleet's 2nd-in-Command Vice-Admiral Returns Units to Gibraltar on September 30th
events.description: Return of Units under Vice-Admiral Commanding, 2nd-in-Command, Home Fleet to Gibraltar, 30th September (D.6).

events.title: Suspicious Echoes and Explosions: U-Boat Activity Detected Off Coastal Waters
events.description: 160. During the night 29th/30th September, between 0325 and 0408, R.D.F. gave echoes suggesting a U-Boat, and several explosions, assumed to have been torpedoes exploding at the end of run, were heard.

events.title: Royal Navy's 8th Cruiser Squadron Heads to Gibraltar: Maneuvers Set for September 30-October 1
events.description: manding, x8th Cruiser Squadron to Gibraltar, 30th September/1st October (D.6/7).
